text: need your feedback :smile:
why are you using a jar file for the jsoup dependency and not via a gradle dependency?
mmm good point i will edit it
Also: `e.printStackTrace();`?
Hardcoded strings aren’t the best thing to do, changing the title of the dialog is not possible.
sad that there is still no other way to check app version in market
`getSharedPreferences` so many times, just do it once in the constructor

having a library for it is nice, but I refuse to check versions like this
it is completely ridiculous that there is no supported way to do it
I tend to just use TagManager for version checks, it gives a lot more flexibility, because you can just return a Json object, and non-technical people can also update it from the website
<@U055JANKU>:  okay thanks
yeah i searched a lot for supported way but didn’t found any result
so i decided to make it
:thumbsup:

there is also this library for version check: <http://btkelly.github.io/gandalf/>
that also uses a Json file, it's not just a Play store check

> it's not just a Play store check
AFAIK, it's not Play store check at all. You need to keep JSON file somewhere in the Internets by yourself
yes and edit json everytime release new version
all libraries use this logic
<https://github.com/danielemaddaluno/Android-Update-Checker>

attachments.title: danielemaddaluno/Android-Update-Checker
attachments.text: Contribute to Android-Update-Checker development by creating an account on GitHub.

text: this is the best one i found but theres no force close on skip , remind me later or callback
Honestly, I just put a textfile up on my server with the current version code and check that in the app. no libraries and their overhead. Just 20 lines of code for a fancy dialog.
i was about to do this
but my leader against anything that require human input :smile:
i think this way is easy and flexible

it is easy to check the Play store
the issue is that Google can change the HTML and then everyone is fucked
That’s why I chose the self hosted one :smile: You can easily automate that too if you want. Especially if you let gradle push to play store
Then you just push the versionCode to the server too
Now that makes me wonder if people would be interested in a simple server side app that has an API for setting and retrieving current version codes
if they change HTML we will change code until they provide supported way
:joy:
If they change HTML it defeats the whole purpose of letting users know to update :wink: Until then they don’t see any dialog.
yes :disappointed:
well, in <@U0H682HMM> 's library they will always see a dialog, because there is no check if the retrieved version is null or empty :wink:
I think Google is trying to say you need to make apps such way that you don't need to check for update in the Market

I don't really understand what usecase there is to notify a user of a play store update. I understand that it's frustrating that there is no native way to find out the version but why would someone want to force an update on a user? I'm not trying to shit on <@U0H682HMM> 's library I am just genuinely curious
Some people never update, then they start complaining that things are broken. But you’ve fixed those issues in your current version.
<@U0QR3EL4W>:  there is callback you can there is check if the retrieved version is null or empty and can hide dialog
in some apps you must update because in old version may features disables
you might update your api and do not want to provide backward compatibility forever
at some point, people will have to update
There could also be some critical security updates
there are these humans that are afraid of changes, so they never ever update. so you have to force them
I have a usecase like this where old apps might stop working if users don’t update
rare edge case tho imho
yes
Same app also tells the user if their clock is not set right :smile:
for example i disable auto-update and always forget to update apps
there is games remind me to update
and other force me to update to play or use the app
Hmm the api deprecation and the security reasons seem quite good reasons

> Hmm the api deprecation and the security reasons seems quite good reasons
However, both there reasons assume that you have server side and can store JSON file somewhere to use with Gandalf or other similar lib (or custom approach)
Yeah it's unavoidable until we get proper support for this
We also have this check and there is just another API method for that on server side. It somehow connected with Git repository, but I don't know exactly how
so what’s your rate for mine ? :smile:

attachments.title: Error in Volley Patch
attachments.text: com.android.volley.NoConnectionError: java.net.ProtocolException: Unknown method 'PATCH'; must be one of [OPTIONS, GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE] StringRequest putRequest = new

text: well, this shows exactly what you have to do if you want to use okhttp as base for volley
but the idea to do it is insane, since okhttp offers everything you need for network requests, as does volley.
but the question is that from this example from stackoverflow I still be confused

Volley is a library for HTTP requests, OkHttp is a library for HTTP requests
I don't understand why you would use both
It’s in the stackoverflow question.
<@U0JBR7LUV>: Volley should support PATCH natively. Since nov 13, 2013.
Specify Method.PATCH for your request.
<http://stackoverflow.com/a/20221780/1074080>

text: What volley version are you using exactly?
volley:library:1.0.19'

<@U055JANKU>: it looks like the best answer
```
it is showing this error in Kitkat, but not in Lollipop. I guess the main problem is that HTTPUrlConnection of Java does not support PATCH. (I guess it works in Lollipop because it is using Java 7 and HTTPUrlConnection of Java 7 supports PATCH method?) Anyhow, You can use the OkHttp Library to correct this problem. The okhttp-urlconnection module implements the java.net.HttpURLConnection
```
Can you explain what your issue is exactly? Since that is something I still not understand.
in KitKap PATCH method doesn’t work in Volley
see post above
That I understand. But as I've said twice now: the volley source code makes sure this is no problem.
that’s famous problem
They implemented PATCH for you
Take a look at the link of the source code I sent above
yes, I am using this PATH, but only in KitKat that doesn’t work
Well. Using OkHttp just to handle a PATCH request on top of Volley is a bad idea. Then it would be better to replace Volley by OkHttp completely. Or maybe even Retrofit.
unfortunately I can't
Why not? What is so different about OkHttp that you cannot use it?
look at this

and then 
```
        Volley.newRequestQueue(application, new OkHttpStack());
```
but for some reason it doesn’t work too :simple_smile:
but its closer :simple_smile:
I can’t help you with using OkHttp on top of Volley.
I still don't understand why you would use an HTTP library inside of an HTTP library, it makes no sense in my head

change to OkHttp or retrofit
